newsitem.title: UK: European duty-paid zinc premiums spike up.
newsitem.headline: European duty-paid zinc premiums spike up.

text.p: Physical premiums for duty-paid zinc have shot up dramatically in Europe over the past two weeks although at higher levels business has thinned out, physical traders said on Wednesday.
Premiums over London Metal Exchange (LME) cash in Rotterdam were being quoted at $50/$55, with one trader citing business at $55. Just two weeks ago, the premium was closer to $30/$35.

"My feeling is someone was aggressively bidding it up to that level -- either a consumer who needed material and was short covering before the summer period, or else someone with a major interest in getting premiums up," a trader said.
"One day it quoted at $30/$35 and then we heard someone paid $50 for two-three lots, just to have the number," another said.
Prices were also high in the European currencies, with the dollar at a 40-month peak against the mark.
Duty-paid zinc was not readily available in any large quantities in Rotterdam, while total LME stocks were down 1,475 tonnes at 411,625 tonnes on Wednesday, traders said.

"There is not that much freely available duty-paid material. Interested parties seem to be holding it back," a trader said. "It takes more than a phone call or two to get decent quantities together. I think someone is sitting on it," he added.
Demand has declined with the soaring cost of physical metal, several traders said. The cash price for zinc was around $1,450, roughly $100 higher than a month ago.
"With the cash price up and premiums high, business isn't outrageous. But demand is there and I'm sure when the market comes off a bit buying will step in," one said.
Another said demand currently was more or less hand to mouth, with consumers buying on small price dips.

"I think this will all end in tears. If the price reaches $1,500 everyone will open their doors to deliver to the LME. There are also indications that some Eastern bloc countries are holding deliverable stock," he added.
One trader also speculated that if the cash/threes contango -- currently at $6/$3 -- narrowed further below the cost of financing then warrant holders may drop premiums to get rid of the metal.

European producers were generally said to be running fully sold books: "It's only when we can squeeze out an extra 100 tonnes or if someone doesn't take 25 tonnes for a certain reason for a week or so that it frees things up a bit," a trader said.
Meanwhile duty-unpaid material was being quoted at a premium of $20/$25, while CIS material ranged from a discount of $5/$10 for medium sized parcels to level for smaller amounts.
